Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Elucidating conformational landscapes in proteins using high-sensitivity pulse EPR spectroscopy
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Stefan Stoll of the University of Washington is developing high-sensitivity instrumentation and methodology for the determination of the nanoscale structure of flexible proteins. The flexibility of proteins is a prerequisite for their activity, but is difficult to quantify experimentally. The methods developed in this project provide tools to accurately probe fundamental chemical processes underlying life at the molecular level. The broader impacts include potential benefits to human health, as the molecular-level knowledge attainable through the methods developed in this project furthers our ability to rationally design new drugs and therapies.

This project focuses on instrumentation development of high-sensitivity pulse electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopies for biostructural applications, specifically double electron-electron resonance (DEER) spectroscopy. DEER is a pulse EPR technique that can quantitatively determine protein conformational distributions and flexibility by measuring nanometer-scale distances between spin labels attached to proteins. The research approach consists of three thrusts: (1) Develop a pulse EPR spectrometer with improved sensitivity for DEER and related methods to be able to accurately measure conformational landscapes in proteins and complexes even at very low concentrations. (2) Quantify protein conformational change in a small soluble ligand-binding protein to benchmark the methodology and to gain insight into conformational dynamics and equilibria involved in ligand binding. (3) Elucidate the conformational landscape in fragments of a cardiac ion channel, in order to test and validate the methodology on a more complex membrane protein system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed novel instruments and software for a biostructural analysis method called DEER (double electron-electron resonance) spectroscopy, which is a high-resolution form of EPR (electron paramagnetic resonance) spectroscopy. DEER measures the nanometer-scale distance between two molecular magnetic tags attached to a protein and thereby reveals the structure and flexibility of proteins. Such information are crucial for increasing our insight into how proteins work.

The project developed novel methodology to increase sensitivity and resolution of DEER spectroscopy, particularly involving a new technology called pulse shaping. As a result, samples with lower protein concentrations can be reliably investigated. In addition, the project identified the molecular mechanism that drives sensitivity loss in DEER spectroscopy and was able to quantitatively reproduce it using quantum-theoretical simulations. This provides a basis of further sensitivity improvements.

The project developed improved statistical analysis methodology to assess uncertainty in the conclusions derived from DEER data, thus increasing rigor and reproducibility. The analysis methods allow extraction of information from noisy data that were previously deemed of insufficient signal-to-noise ratio.

The project resulted in extended capabilities of the open-source scientific software EasySpin, which provides simulation and analysis methods for EPR spectroscopy. Several national training workshops were organized. The educational aspects of the project also resulted in a freely available online undergraduate-level textbook on physical chemistry and a novel curriculum that trains chemistry graduate students in coding, a skill of increasing importance across all areas of natural science.
